Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Activation Station Technology for In-line Solar String Inspection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable manufacturers of solar cell assemblies to conduct quality control in real time. potentially reducing the cost of the solar cell modules and increasing production by an estimated 26%. Prospective customers of the envisioned technology are firms that make the assemblies (known as "strings"), and specifically producers of cell stringer tools. The system will have other renewable market applications, such as testing cracks on incoming silicon wafers prior to vacuum deposition of thin layers for back-side solar cells. The production-grade systems at the initial commercialization step will be made domestically, creating new jobs. In Phase I, Ultrasonic Technologies will team with a US-based module producer to integrate and validate the prototype in a commercial stringer and production environment. The project will be supported by two university research teams which provide education and training of graduate students in a high-tech production facility.

The proposed project will demonstrate a multi-head Activation Station (AS) system, using controllable mechanical stress applied to the cell string through a specially designed multi-head vacuum chuck. The string stressing is followed by fast measurements of the responding deflection of the cell caused by vacuum loading. This deflection provides a sensitive means to assess the cell's mechanical integrity and to exhibit any hidden invisible cracks. The cell deflection also provides real-time control for how tight the technological parameters are of the stringing processes, e.g., annealing temperature, soldering thickness and soldering quality. A new AS method for rapid in-line crack detection in strings will adhere to a throughput rate of 4,200 cells per hour or a cycle time of 0.85 seconds per cell in modern production stringers. In parallel, the vacuum chuck design will be optimized to assure a high level of crack coverage which will be quantified through experimentation. Finite Element Analyses model will support the experimental data of crack inspection accuracy and sensitivity of the AS technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SBIR Phase I project addressed a critical need in Photovoltaic (PV) module manufacturing: to inspect in real-time mechanical quality of crystalline Silicon solar cell strings using in-line vacuum Activation Station (vAS) technology. In Phase I we proved the feasibility of the vAS concept for solar cell strings and complete initial development of the vAS methodology by designing, assembling, and testing in the laboratory the programmable vAS system prototype. The Phase I project was supported by comprehensive experiments and Finite Element Analyses computer simulation by creating stress maps of cell strings under vacuum. The goal of the entire SBIR project is to improve the throughput of commercial solar module lines by identifying and eliminating solar cells with hidden cracks at the initial stage of PV module production. A general concept of the in-line vAS involves applying controllable mechanical stress to all cells in a string through multi-head vacuum chucks and quick measurements of the vacuum pressure causing deflection of cells in the string. The vacuum level provides a sensitive means to assess the cell?s mechanical integrity and hidden cracks. The vAS method and system are protected by pending US patent application.

The technical objectives OF phase I are summarized as follows:

O1: Perform Finite Element Analysis (FEA) to model stress profile on Si cell with attached cupper ribbons caused by vacuum loading, optimize vAS design, and enhance the accuracy of crack detection.

O2: Design and manufacture a laboratory vAS prototype (hardware and software) that will lead to a pre-production system prototype in Phase II.

O3: Identify crack locations across the cells in the string that are not covered by the vAS tool (blind areas). Correlate them with FEA predictions and minimize blind areas by optimizing vAS chuck design.

O4: Experimentally prove that the vAS crack inspection concept can match the throughput rate of production stringers across industry standards.

O5: Initiate a product development of the v-AS system with potential end-users to proceed with commercialization of the innovation.

The Conclusions of Phase I are as follows:

1.1  In Phase I we performed feasibility research and proved that vAS technology is viable for silicon solar cells connected in strings.
1.2  Designed, manufactured, and tested vAS laboratory prototype demonstrated (a) non-invasiveness to non-cracked cells, (b) cycle time matching to fastest commercial stringers, (c) high accuracy and sensitivity to seed cracks.
1.3  Finite Element Analyses modeling of stress profile in cells with attached ribbons accurately describes the technology and provides a theoretical background for the vAS algorithm.
1.4  Experimental results of vacuum stress for seed crack activation show good correlation with FEA data of the stress profile in cell string under vacuum pressure.
1.5  Performed R&D in Phase I project created a foundation for the next phase of product development in the Phase II project.
1.6  In Phase II, the pre-production vAS prototype for up to 12-cell strings will be designed, manufactured, and tested. It will pass qualification in solar module production.
1.7  Phase II project will target the integration of the vAS pre-production prototype in commercial module line equipment with our commercial partner.
1.8 vAS method and system are protected by the US patent application (pending). 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/20/2020
Modified by: Sergei Ostapenko
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The SBIR Phase I project addressed a critical need in Photovoltaic (PV) module manufacturing: to inspect in real-time mechanical quality of crystalline Silicon solar cell strings using in-line vacuum Activation Station (vAS) technology. In Phase I we proved the feasibility of the vAS concept for solar cell strings and complete initial development of the vAS methodology by designing, assembling, and testing in the laboratory the programmable vAS system prototype. The Phase I project was supported by comprehensive experiments and Finite Element Analyses computer simulation by creating stress maps of cell strings under vacuum. The goal of the entire SBIR project is to improve the throughput of commercial solar module lines by identifying and eliminating solar cells with hidden cracks at the initial stage of PV module production. A general concept of the in-line vAS involves applying controllable mechanical stress to all cells in a string through multi-head vacuum chucks and quick measurements of the vacuum pressure causing deflection of cells in the string. The vacuum level provides a sensitive means to assess the cell?s mechanical integrity and hidden cracks. The vAS method and system are protected by pending US patent application. The technical objectives OF phase I are summarized as follows: O1: Perform Finite Element Analysis (FEA) to model stress profile on Si cell with attached cupper ribbons caused by vacuum loading, optimize vAS design, and enhance the accuracy of crack detection. O2: Design and manufacture a laboratory vAS prototype (hardware and software) that will lead to a pre-production system prototype in Phase II. O3: Identify crack locations across the cells in the string that are not covered by the vAS tool (blind areas). Correlate them with FEA predictions and minimize blind areas by optimizing vAS chuck design. O4: Experimentally prove that the vAS crack inspection concept can match the throughput rate of production stringers across industry standards. O5: Initiate a product development of the v-AS system with potential end-users to proceed with commercialization of the innovation. The Conclusions of Phase I are as follows: 1.1 In Phase I we performed feasibility research and proved that vAS technology is viable for silicon solar cells connected in strings. 1.2 Designed, manufactured, and tested vAS laboratory prototype demonstrated (a) non-invasiveness to non-cracked cells, (b) cycle time matching to fastest commercial stringers, (c) high accuracy and sensitivity to seed cracks. 1.3 Finite Element Analyses modeling of stress profile in cells with attached ribbons accurately describes the technology and provides a theoretical background for the vAS algorithm. 1.4 Experimental results of vacuum stress for seed crack activation show good correlation with FEA data of the stress profile in cell string under vacuum pressure. 1.5 Performed R&D in Phase I project created a foundation for the next phase of product development in the Phase II project. 1.6 In Phase II, the pre-production vAS prototype for up to 12-cell strings will be designed, manufactured, and tested. It will pass qualification in solar module production. 1.7 Phase II project will target the integration of the vAS pre-production prototype in commercial module line equipment with our commercial partner. 1.8 vAS method and system are protected by the US patent application (pending).
